Title: Is COVID-19 the first pandemic that evolves into a panzootic?
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Infected dogs, infected cats, infected tigers, infected lions
Conclusion Excerpt: With the current information available it is not possible to predict if SARS-CoV-2 will cause a panzootic.

Title: A rapid review of evidence of infection of pets and livestock with human-associated coronavirus diseases, SARS, MERS, and COVID-19, and evidence of the fomite potential of pets and livestock
Animals Studied / Cases: cats, dogs, ferrets, pigs, chickens, ducks
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Infected ferrets, infected cats, infected dogs
Conclusion Excerpt: There is evidence from seeder models that cats and ferrets can become infected with SARSCoV-2 and this is detectable using PCR. There is evidence that cats in Wuhan, China have antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 which appears to have developed after the outbreak. Dogs may become infected and produce antibodies, but there is no evidence that they develop clinical disease if exposed, or that they shed virus which may pose a risk to humans.

Title: Serological survey of SARS‐CoV‐2 for experimental, domestic, companion and wild animals excludes intermediate hosts of 35 different species of animals
Animals Studied / Cases: pigs, cows, sheep, horses, chickens, ducks, geese, mice, rats, guinea pigs, rabbits, monkeys, dogs, cats, camels, foxes, minks, alpacas, ferrets, bamboo rats, peacocks, eagles, tigers, rhinoceroses, pangolins, leopard cats, jackels, giant pandas, masked civets, porcupines, bears, yellow-throated martens, weasels, red pandas, wild boars
Conclusion Excerpt: No SARS-CoV-2 specific antibodies were detected.

Title: An Overview of SARS‐CoV‐2 and Animal Infection
Animals Studied / Cases: Bats, Pangolin, Cats, Dogs, Ferrets, snakes, turtles
Detection Methods: Binding affinity of Sars-COV2 protein to ACE-2 receptors in animals,
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Virus detected in Upper respiratory tract of Ferrets and Cats
Conclusion Excerpt: Trasmission to humans possibile from: Bats, Pangolin, Cats (Upper respiratory tract), Dogs .  Not Hosts: Snakes, Turtles

Title: COVID-19 and pets: When pandemic meets panic
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Infected cats, infected dogs, infected tigers
Conclusion Excerpt: No significant data to support transmission occurs between cats/dogs/tigers/humans

Title: Absence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in cats and dogs in close contact with a cluster of COVID-19 patients in a veterinary campus
Conclusion Excerpt: Our study points to undetectable interspecific transmission of the SARS-CoV-2 virus between COVID-19 patients and domestic dogs or cats under the natural exposure conditions.

Title: Infection and Rapid Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in Ferrets
Sample: serum, nasal washes, saliva, urine, feces, organ tissue samples
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Infected ferrets, ferret to ferret transmission
Conclusion Excerpt: SARS-CoV-2 was found to efficiently infect ferrets.

Title: Can companion animals become infected with Covid-19?
Conclusion Excerpt: The consensus remains at this time that there is no evidence that infected pets are a source of infection for people or other pets.

Title: SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing serum antibodies in cats: a serological investigation
Conclusion Excerpt: These results demonstrated that SARS-CoV-2 has infected cat populations in Wuhan, implying that this risk could also occur at other outbreak regions.

Title: Susceptibility of ferrets, cats, dogs, and different domestic animals to SARS-coronavirus-2
Animals Studied / Cases: ferrets, cats, dogs, pigs, chickens, ducks
Sample: organ tissue samples, nasal washes, rectal swabs, feces
Detection Methods: qPCR, virus titration, ELISA, histology (H&E, IHC)
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Infected ferrets, infected cats, cat to cat transmission, infected dogs
Conclusion Excerpt: We found that ferrets and cats are highly susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, dogs have low susceptibility, and livestock including pigs, chickens, and ducks are not susceptible to the virus.

Title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Outbreak: Could Pigs Be Vectors for Human Infections?
Sample: six pigs, 2 were Antibody (+) 1 was Ag (+)
Evidence of Infection / Transmission: Presence of antigen and virus on nasal swabs of the pig
Conclusion Excerpt: No evidence of pigs being infected with SARS-COV2 or capable of amplifying the virus
